Wage Growth and Inflation Signal

Wage growth and inflation composite: assessing labour-cost pressures and price dynamics.

As of 2026-01-01

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The Wage Growth & Inflation composite signal currently indicates a NEUTRAL regime. Both wage pressure and broader inflation components remain within their typical ranges (1).
  • The latest `private_wage_yoy` is 3.6% and `civilian_wage_yoy` is 3.5%, with the `Inflation_Composite_z` at -0.546746.
  • Conviction Band: Medium, Interpretation Confidence: High Confidence, Internal Conflict Flag: No.

Key Dynamics:

  • The main drivers are `Wage_Pressure_z` at -0.357684 and `Labor_Tightness_z` at -0.735808, which are both moderately negative but firmly within the neutral band of the signal's thresholds (1).
  • Recent momentum suggests a stabilization of wage pressure around neutral levels, following earlier periods of more pronounced moderation.
  • No material internal offsets; both wage and labor tightness indicators are coherent in signaling a neutral regime.
  • Conditional Invalidation: A sustained move of the `Inflation_Composite_z` above +1.0 (HOT conditions) or below -1.0 (COOL/disinflationary conditions) would invalidate this neutral interpretation (1).

Scenario Balance:

  • Base Case dominant; risks balanced. Wage and inflation pressures are expected to remain in a neutral state, reflecting stable wage growth and balanced labor market tightness (1).
  • Most plausible upside risk: A material re-acceleration in either private or civilian wage growth, or a significant tightening of the labor market, pushing the composite z-score above +1.0.
  • Most plausible downside risk: Further deceleration in wage growth combined with a noticeable weakening of labor market tightness, driving the composite z-score below -1.0.

Time Horizon & Aggregation:

  • Time Horizon: Cyclical (months). This signal blends quarterly ECI data with monthly LMT, smoothed to capture medium-term inflation momentum (1).
  • Aggregation Weight Hint: Medium. As a fundamental indicator of inflation, it provides valuable input to broader macro themes, though its current neutral stance suggests no strong directional bias.

Macro Relevance:

  • This signal primarily informs the Pricing (inflation) and Slack (labour market) dimensions of the macro economy (1).
  • A neutral regime suggests the economy is not experiencing extreme inflationary or disinflationary wage dynamics, aligning with a mid-to-late cycle moderation phase.
  • It typically interacts with other inflation signals, such as PCE (3) and CPI vs PPI divergence (4), and other labor market indicators like Labor Market Tightness (2), to provide a holistic economic assessment.

Data & References:

  • Employment Cost Index (ECI) for Private Industry Wages & Salaries (CIU2020000000000A) and Civilian Workers Wages & Salaries (CIU1020000000000A), latest available quarterly data up-sampled to monthly (1).
  • Labor Market Tightness (LMT) z-score, integrated monthly (1).
  • The most influential datapoints are `Wage_Pressure_z` (-0.357684) and `Labor_Tightness_z` (-0.735808), which average to form `Inflation_Composite_z` (-0.546746).
  • Additional public datasets that would improve depth or reliability include the BLS Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) (2) and the Federal Reserve's Beige Book for qualitative wage and price commentary (5).
